title: Tokyo stocks close higher on US rallies, cheap yen
text:
Tokyo stocks closed higher for a four-day winning streak on Thursday, helped by rallies on Wall Street and a cheaper yen against the dollar.

The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.55 percent, or 125.22 points, to end at 22,750.60, while the broader Topix index was up 0.34 percent, or 5.60 points, to 1,643.74.

"The Nikkei index rose thanks to the gains of US shares and a cheaper yen," Yoshihiro Ito, chief strategist at Okasan Online Securities said.

The dollar fetched 108.62 yen in Asian trade, against 108.65 yen in New York and 108.33 yen in Tokyo late Wednesday.

The dollar's strength partly reflected brisk US corporate earnings and optimism over US-China trade talks, analysts said.

In Tokyo, chip-making equipment manufacturer Tokyo Electron jumped 2.17 percent to 21,335 yen, industrial robot maker Fanuc rose 1.19 percent to 21,200 yen, and Toyota was up 0.88 percent at 7,486 yen.

SoftBank Group dropped 2.93 percent to 4,067 yen after a report the company plans to seek approval of its WeWork bailout package with a US government committee that reviews corporate deals for national security risks.

Pharmaceutical firm Eisai, which announced on Tuesday a plan to seek US approval for its alzheimer's drug, soared 15.30 percent to 7,534 yen.

On Wall Street, the Dow ended up 0.2 percent. The broad-based S&P 500 climbed 0.3 percent, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.2 percent.
